TopicTitle: [WIP] NASA SLS - Released: Orion MPCV Core Module 1.0 [4/18/2015]

Articles.Content:
So I noticed something today that kind of made me lose interest in this project a bit.

My primary motivation for doing this was I saw the SLS and noticed a lack of anything like it in game. So I was excited to do it. There were a few stockish projects. So I said to myself, I'll do this at full 8.4m scale to make it unique.

Then today, I noticed in the ChakaMonkey Beta 0.12 release, there are 8.4m parts. I have only recently started follow YANFRET's endeavors, so I don't know if it's a new addition or was originally planned and I missed it. Regardless, everyone contributing to ChakaMonkey are much better modelers, texture artists, etc., than I am and now that they are (or have been?) doing 8.4m scaled parts, I see little point in continuing what I've been doing here.

As such, I putting the MPCV/LUS/etc on the back burner and shifting the goals of this project. I will release them eventually, but I see little point in concentrating solely on them as there are higher quality versions of exactly the thing already available. However, I will eventually finish them and release them because I said I would and I'm not the sort of person to leave something half finished.

Instead, I'll be concentrating on the other components planned for the SLS.

Such as:

The Lunar Radio Telescope

Mars (Duna) Surface Mission

The Advanced Technology Large-Aperture Space Telescope (ATLAST)

and

The Solar Probe 2

To reiterate: I'm not abandoning this project, just shifting priorities. The Upper Stage and Orion will eventually be completed (although I really don't see a point, I just can't leave something unfinished). I will just be putting priority on the other parts.

That being said... I think I'll go start modeling the ATLAST. Looking at that thing makes my mouth water

Forth Coming Project

Preliminary "Rough" model of the ATLAIR ascent pod with placeholder texture.
Interesting design with those side tanks. It looks a bit thin to be able to fit three people. Looking forward to how the SLS payloads will turn out!

Interesting design with those side tanks. It looks a bit thin to be able to fit three people. Looking forward to how the SLS payloads will turn out!

It's just the ascent module for the ALTAIR lander. It's only a small portion of the intended lander and used primarily just to ferry people from the surface to the Orion in orbit.

Here is the (maybe) finished untextured model

I wouldn't give up...chaka monkey is a group effort of over a dozen individual modders. I use chaka monkey myself and it is wonderful. An independent development of a kerbal sls is an amazing endeavor, my suggestion is to attempt to add a kerbal flavor to your designs to differentiate yourself.

I wouldn't give up...chaka monkey is a group effort of over a dozen individual modders. I use chaka monkey myself and it is wonderful. An independent development of a kerbal sls is an amazing endeavor, my suggestion is to attempt to add a kerbal flavor to your designs to differentiate yourself.

We have decided to join forces to enhance the overall product. That way noonespecial can release systems that one day will add up to his original project goals while enhancing Chaka Monkey along the way. The revised Altair pod at the bottom of the previous page is the first result of our cooperation, that is... my suggestion, his execution. And what a magnificent model it is already!!!

It's just the ascent module for the ALTAIR lander. It's only a small portion of the intended lander and used primarily just to ferry people from the surface to the Orion in orbit.

Here is the (maybe) finished untextured model

Exactly. This way we can all move forward together without getting bogged down with continuously perfecting the launch vehicle. And when there is a fleet of nice payloads inspired by the Boeing PDF, we can get back to re making Orion and SLS.

It's so beautiful!

Isn't it ironic that you are producing SLS accurately as it is planned alone and Yanfret is producing a mix of multiple packs of the community to make an SLS which fits KSP sizes (iirc)?

It's funny because realistic SLS is actually a joint project from a lot of companies for NASA too. XDDD

NOS Explorer Pod

NOS Explorer Pod by noonespecial on Sketchfab

NOS Explorer Pod + Very WIP/Will be Redesigned Lander

Lander by noonespecial on Sketchfab
Is there a reason why those thrusters are so polyfull?

Is there a reason why those thrusters are so polyfull?

Because at the rendering of this model, I had yet to do the detail work on those particular pieces, so instead just hit it with a subsurface for the sake of the rendering. The small thrusters are actually hexagons and the large thrusters are decagons with the base being an octagon.
Not that high poly counts matter all that much these days (alas, unless you're ferram and are basically the only person KSP is GPU, not CPU-limited for...)

Update 8/30/14

Mars (Duna) lander.

In three pieces. The Upper Tanks, The Lower Utility (with landing gear), and radial attached RCS engines.

Where did you find this reference material? The stuff that I have seen had a radically different design.

There's a concept for a Mars lander in this PDF from NASA, it's about Boeing's plans for lunar and Martian landers. It's from 2011, I believe, so maybe it's not current. They do show it with the SLS, though it's the older SLS design with five engines (new one has four engines) and the old Orion MPCV design is shown as well.. Hope this helps!

http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/604643main_2-Panel%202_Donahue_Final.pdf

Sadder question: what GPU.

I'm confused, Nathan --- for ferram4, does he have a very good CPU and a bad GPU, or a very good CPU and his GPU is very good, but being limited by KSP? Or maybe something else?

I'm using the pictures from the Boeing SLS booklet, which was released in January 2014. Sometimes, I use information from the EAS if it is more recent (such as with the service module).

http://www.boeing.com/assets/pdf/defense-space/space/sls/docs/sls_mission_booklet_jan_2014.pdf

http://www.boeing.com/assets/pdf/defense-space/space/sls/docs/sls_mission_booklet_jan_2014.pdf

This is a pretty good source, very recent with lots of pictures:

http://spirit.as.utexas.edu/~fiso/telecon/Raftery_5-14-14/Raftery_5-14-14.pdf

The lander there looks similar to the one in the booklet.
